title: New Israel-Gaza ceasefire plan proposed, Hamas source tells BBC
snippets: Egyptian and Qatari mediators suggest a truce of up to seven years and a permanent end to the war.
titles: New Israel-Gaza ceasefire plan proposed, Hamas source tells BBC
constructiveness_reason: This story highlights a potential solution to an ongoing conflict, providing readers with a sense of progress and deeper understanding of the situation.
summary: Egyptian and Qatari mediators have proposed a truce that could last up to seven years, aiming for a permanent cessation of hostilities. This initiative seeks to bring a long-term resolution to the conflict, though the current status of acceptance by the involved parties remains unspecified.

title: Putin suggests Russia open to direct talks with Ukraine, as strikes continue
snippets: Moscow launched strikes across Ukrainian cities hours after Putin said he was considering a pause on civilian targets.
titles: Putin suggests Russia open to direct talks with Ukraine, as strikes continue
constructiveness_reason: This story informs about a significant development in the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. It provides useful context even though the topic is negative.
summary: Hours after President Putin indicated a potential pause on targeting civilian areas, Moscow initiated strikes across various Ukrainian cities. This action directly contradicts the earlier statement made by the Russian leader.

title: Who will be the next Pope? Key candidates in an unpredictable contest
snippets: Several names are in the fray as cardinals prepare to gather in the Vatican to elect Pope Francis' successor.
titles: Who will be the next Pope? Key candidates in an unpredictable contest
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information and context about potential candidates for the next Pope, contributing to readers' understanding of the process.
summary: Cardinals are set to convene at the Vatican to select the successor to Pope Francis. Multiple candidates are being considered for the position, indicating a significant upcoming decision for the Catholic Church's leadership.

title: Why Pope's death leaves Argentines 'orphaned' in more ways than one
snippets: Pope Francis was a source of pride for Argentina - but his failure to visit was a disappointment for many.
titles: Why Pope's death leaves Argentines 'orphaned' in more ways than one
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful context about the emotional impact of Pope Francis's death on Argentines, contributing to readers' understanding of the global significance of this event.
summary: Pope Francis, originally from Argentina, has been a source of national pride for the country. However, his decision not to visit Argentina during his papacy has led to widespread disappointment among Argentinians.

title: Mission to boldly grow food in space labs blasts off
snippets: The mission will explore new ways of reducing the cost of feeding an astronaut.
titles: Mission to boldly grow food in space labs blasts off
constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights progress and innovation in space exploration and food production. It provides empowering knowledge about the potential for growing food in space.
summary: A new mission aims to discover innovative methods to lower the expenses associated with providing food for astronauts. This initiative seeks to address the significant challenge of sustaining space crew nutrition in a cost-effective manner, potentially revolutionizing the approach to food supply for long-duration space missions.

title: Devils won't have injured defensemen Luke Hughes, Brenden Dillon for Game 2 against Hurricanes
snippets: New Jersey Devils defensemen Luke Hughes and Brenden Dillon are out with injuries for Tuesday night's Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against the Carolina Hurricanes.  Coach Sheldon Keefe ruled out both Hughes and Dillon after neither participated in the morning skate.  Keefe didn't specify the nature of those injuries, which are another hit for a squad that was already down prominent pieces before the Stanley Cup Playoffs.
titles: Devils won't have injured defensemen Luke Hughes, Brenden Dillon for Game 2 against Hurricanes
summary: New Jersey Devils defensemen Luke Hughes and Brenden Dillon will miss Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against the Carolina Hurricanes due to injuries. Coach Sheldon Keefe confirmed their absence after both players did not participate in the morning skate. The specific nature of their injuries was not disclosed. This development adds to the challenges for the Devils, who were already facing the loss of key players heading into the Stanley Cup Playoffs.

title: NBA DFS: DraftKings, FanDuel daily Fantasy basketball picks for Tuesday, April 22 include Pascal Siakam

titles: NBA DFS: DraftKings, FanDuel daily Fantasy basketball picks for Tuesday, April 22 include Pascal Siakam
summary: Mike McClure, a professional in daily Fantasy sports with over $2 million in winnings, provided his expert NBA DFS lineup advice for Tuesday, April 22, as reported by SportsLine.

title: Wisconsin relies on new QB and coordinator to boost an offense that has struggled under Luke Fickell
snippets: The team is coming off its first losing season in more than two decades. If the Badgers don’t bounce back, plenty of people could be on thin ice.
titles: Wisconsin relies on new QB and coordinator to boost an offense that has struggled under Luke Fickell
summary: The Badgers, having experienced their first losing season in over 20 years, face pressure to improve their performance. If they fail to bounce back, it could jeopardize the positions of numerous individuals involved with the team.

title: New York Giants' Tyler Nubin explains switch to jersey No. 27
snippets: New York Giants safety Tyler Nubin is changing his number from 31 to 27, the same number he wore as a Minnesota Golden Gopher.
titles: New York Giants' Tyler Nubin explains switch to jersey No. 27
summary: Tyler Nubin, a safety for the New York Giants, has decided to change his jersey number from 31 to 27, reverting to the same number he wore during his college football career with the Minnesota Golden Gophers.

title: Jay Powell is defiant in the face of Trump’s threats
snippets: The Fed chair is determined to see out his term, and lawyers at the central bank think he has good grounds to do so
titles: Jay Powell is defiant in the face of Trump’s threats
summary: The Federal Reserve Chair is committed to completing his term, supported by the central bank's legal team who believe he has a strong basis for remaining in his position.

title: Gold hits $3,500 for first time as Trump’s attack on Powell rattles markets
snippets: S&P 500 rebounds but criticism of Fed chair fuels demand for haven assets
titles: Gold hits $3,500 for first time as Trump’s attack on Powell rattles markets
summary: The S&P 500 experienced a rebound amidst ongoing criticism of the Federal Reserve Chair, which has increased investors' demand for safe-haven assets. This situation reflects market reactions to the Federal Reserve's policies and the public critique of its leadership, impacting investment trends and asset preferences.

title: Top Stock Movers Now: 3M, Tesla, Equifax, and More
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Market enthusiasm for corporate earnings helped U.S. equities climb at midday, rebounding from yesterday's selloff.
  • Tesla shares gained ahead of tonight's much-anticipated earnings report by the electric vehicle maker.
  • A warning about tariff costs dragged down shares of Kimberly-Clark.


U.S. equities bounced back from yesterday's sharp selloff at midday as investors turned their focus away from macroeconomic concerns to corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all rose about 2%.

3M (MMM) was the best-performing stock in the Dow after the multinational manufacturing conglomerate reported better-than-expected profit and sales, and gave details of how the Trump administration tariffs could affect future performance.

Shares of Tesla (TSLA) were on pace to snap a three-day losing streak as the market prepared for the electric vehicle (EV) maker's much-anticipated earnings report following the close of trading.

Equifax (EFX) said it overcame weakness in the mortgage and hiring market, posting earnings and revenue that beat forecasts. It also announced a new stock buyback program plus a dividend increase, and shares jumped.

Shares of defense contractors RTX (RTX) and Northrop Grumman (NOC) fell sharply on worries about the impact of tariffs and earnings results.

Halliburton (HAL) shares slumped when the big oilfield services provider reported its first-quarter sales were the lowest in three years as sinking oil prices crimped demand.

Kimberly-Clark (KMB) shares tumbled after the consumer products maker slashed its full-year outlook "to reflect potential incremental costs from a more uncertain geopolitical landscape." 

Oil futures advanced. Gold prices continued their climb. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note dropped. The U.S. dollar was up on the euro, but lost ground to the pound and yen. Most major cryptocurrencies traded higher.
titles: Top Stock Movers Now: 3M, Tesla, Equifax, and More
summary: U.S. equities rebounded with a 2% rise in major indexes due to positive corporate earnings, overshadowing previous macroeconomic worries. 3M led gains in the Dow after reporting strong profits and sales, while Tesla's shares rose in anticipation of its earnings report. Equifax announced a new stock buyback program and a dividend increase after beating earnings forecasts. However, shares of defense contractors RTX and Northrop Grumman, along with Halliburton and Kimberly-Clark, fell due to tariff concerns, earnings results, and a cut in full-year outlook, respectively. Meanwhile, oil futures ad

title: Businesses Look to Their Wealthiest Customers in Uncertain Economy
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Businesses are looking to their wealthiest customers to compensate for a pullback in spending among other consumers.
  • Delta and United airlines have said "premium" ticket sales are booming, along with international travel.
  • Luxury retailers are optimistic that wealthy households' finances can withstand economic uncertainty.


Companies are leaning on their wealthiest customers.

Businesses are hoping affluent Americans' spending will carry them through an economic slowdown. Airlines are relying on “premium” ticket sales, while luxury retailers are optimistic that wealthy households’ finances will hold up—and propel them through the current uncertainty.

“The high-end cohort—in the past four months—we did not see any difference,” said Brunello Cucinelli, founder of an eponymous luxury clothing line. “There is still a lot of openness and desire for good taste and lifestyle," he added.

Sales of inexpensive flights, such as those in the middle of business days, have slowed, Delta Air Lines (DAL) and United Airlines (UAL) said on first-quarter conference calls this month. But business is booming for international and first-class fares, executives said. 

“Premium” tickets are a bigger share of revenue than Delta President Glen Hauenstein said he could recall previously seeing. He doesn’t see these travelers downgrading, according to a transcript made available from AlphaSense.

Wealthy global travelers are buying premium tickets for global trips, said United Chief Commercial Officer Andrew Nocella. "That’s really good for our business,” he said.

High-end apparel and leather goods sales have been strong, but segments that attract more “aspirational” shoppers, including alcohol and cosmetics, may have been impacted by tariffs, said LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, a French luxury goods company.

The company’s response to the import taxes may involve increasing production of Louis Vuitton and Tiffany in the US and raising prices, executives said on a quarterly earnings call last week. It'll also concentrate on wealthy clientele who are less likely to suffer financially, at least initially, CEO Bernard Arnault said at an annual meeting last week.

“This affluent customer segment is far more sustainable,” Arnault said, according to a recording on LVMH’s website. “We are inclined to the view of: let’s favor growth of the highest-end of our products.”

Brunello Cucinelli plans to raise prices 3% to 4% in the second half of 2025 in response to the tariffs, according to a transcript of a recent earnings call.
titles: Businesses Look to Their Wealthiest Customers in Uncertain Economy
summary: Businesses are increasingly targeting their wealthiest customers to maintain revenue amid economic uncertainties. Airlines like Delta and United are experiencing a significant rise in "premium" ticket sales and international travel. Luxury retailers remain optimistic about the financial resilience of wealthy households, expecting them to continue spending on high-end goods. This strategy comes as sales in some sectors, particularly those appealing to more aspirational consumers, face challenges due to tariffs. Companies such as LVMH are considering raising prices and focusing more on luxury pr

title: Defense Contractors RTX, Lockheed, Grumman Post Mixed Results as Tariffs Loom
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Defense contractors reported a mixed set of first-quarter earnings Tuesday ahead of the potential impact of Trump administration tariffs.
  • RTX warned that U.S. tariffs and reciprocal tariffs could drag down full-year operating profit.
  • Northrop Grumman was hit with high costs for its B-21 bomber.
  • Lockheed Martin, maker of the F-35 fighter, exceeded forecasts but its shares also declined.


Shares of RTX (RTX) slumped Tuesday as the defense contractor warned new Trump administration tariffs will impact results. Rival Northrop Grumman (NOC)'s stock also dropped sharply on costs related to the B-21 bomber. Shares of Lockheed Martin (LMT) fell, too, even though the company's results topped estimates as it benefited from higher demand for its weapons.

RTX, whose shares sank 9% soon after the opening bell, said if the tariffs last the year, it may see a negative impact on operating profit of more than three-quarters of a billion dollars. It sees $250 million drops because of levies on Canada and Mexico, plus another $250 million hit from those on China and from China. Global reciprocal tariffs could cause an additional $300 million decline, and steel and aluminum tariffs would add another $50 million.

Northrop Grumman, whose shares dropped 12% to lead early S&P 500 decliners, reported first-quarter profit slumped 47% year-over-year, with earnings per share (EPS) of $3.32 nearly 50% below estimates of analysts surveyed by Visible Alpha. Sales sank 7% to $9.47 billion, also short of forecasts.

The company blamed the weak results on a pre-tax loss of $477 million ($397 million after-tax or $2.74 per diluted share) because of five low-rate initial production (LRIP) options related to the B-21 program. It noted the slide was primarily caused by "a process change made by the company to enable an accelerated production ramp, as well as increases in the projected cost and quantity of general procurement materials."

However, Lockheed Martin posted EPS of $7.28 on revenue that rose 4.5% to $17.96 billion, with both exceeding forecasts. The company's Aeronautics division, which makes the F-35 fighter, reported a sales gain of 3% to $7.06 billion.

Both Lockheed Martin and RTX affirmed their full-year outlooks, although RTX’s guidance didn’t incorporate more recent tariffs.
titles: Defense Contractors RTX, Lockheed, Grumman Post Mixed Results as Tariffs Loom
summary: Defense contractors experienced mixed first-quarter earnings, with RTX warning of a potential drag on profits due to Trump administration tariffs, including a significant impact from levies on Canada, Mexico, and China, as well as reciprocal tariffs globally. Northrop Grumman faced a sharp stock drop due to high costs associated with the B-21 bomber, leading to a significant miss in earnings and sales forecasts. Meanwhile, Lockheed Martin surpassed estimates with higher demand for its F-35 fighter, though its shares also declined. Both Lockheed Martin and RTX maintained their full-year outlook

title: Novel treatment approach for language disorder shows promise
snippets: Neuroscientists have developed a new treatment approach for a language disorder that combines traditional speech therapy with noninvasive electrical stimulation of the brain. Brain stimulation helped induce neuroplasticity, the brain's capacity to continue to reorganize and learn.
titles: Novel treatment approach for language disorder shows promise
summary: Neuroscientists have created a novel treatment for a language disorder, merging traditional speech therapy with noninvasive brain stimulation. This method aims to enhance neuroplasticity, enabling the brain to reorganize and learn more effectively. This innovative approach has shown promise in improving language rehabilitation outcomes.

title: Daily pill could replace weight-loss shots like Ozempic and Wegovy
snippets: A daily pill developed by the US pharmaceutical company Lilly may become a convenient alternative to injectable drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy. In phase III trials it significantly lowered blood sugar and body weight in people with type 2 diabetes
titles: Daily pill could replace weight-loss shots like Ozempic and Wegovy
summary: A new daily pill created by Lilly, a US pharmaceutical company, has shown promising results in phase III trials for people with type 2 diabetes. The medication significantly reduced blood sugar and body weight, potentially offering a more convenient alternative to injectable drugs such as Ozempic and Wegovy.

title: Omnivorous? Vegan? Makes no difference to muscle building after weight training, study finds
snippets: A new study asked three questions about muscle protein synthesis in response to a nine-day diet and weight training regimen: First, does the source of protein -- plant or animal-based -- make any difference to muscle gain? Second, does it matter if total daily protein intake is evenly distributed throughout the day? And third, does a moderate but sufficient daily protein intake influence any of these variables? The answer to all three questions is 'no,' the researchers found.
titles: Omnivorous? Vegan? Makes no difference to muscle building after weight training, study finds
summary: A study investigated the effects of protein source, distribution throughout the day, and moderate intake on muscle protein synthesis during a nine-day diet and weight training regimen. Researchers concluded that neither the type of protein (plant or animal-based), the distribution of protein intake throughout the day, nor a moderate but sufficient daily protein intake significantly affects muscle gains.

title: Did it rain or snow on ancient Mars? New study suggests it did
snippets: Geologists weigh in on a long-running debate about Mars: Billions of years ago, was the Red Planet warm and wet or cold and dry?
titles: Did it rain or snow on ancient Mars? New study suggests it did
summary: Geologists have engaged in a detailed analysis to address a longstanding debate regarding Mars' ancient climate conditions. They are examining whether, billions of years ago, Mars was characterized by a warm and wet environment or was predominantly cold and dry. This research aims to provide clarity on the Red Planet's historical climate, contributing to our understanding of its potential to have supported life.

title: Building 'cellular bridges' for spinal cord repair after injury
snippets: Capitalizing on the flexibility of tiny cells inside the body's smallest blood vessels may be a powerful spinal cord repair strategy, new research suggests.
titles: Building 'cellular bridges' for spinal cord repair after injury
summary: New research suggests that leveraging the adaptability of microscopic cells within the body's tiniest blood vessels could offer an effective strategy for repairing spinal cord injuries. This approach focuses on the potential of these small cells to aid in the regeneration and healing of spinal cord damage.

Researchers concluded that neither the type of protein (plant or animal-based), the distribution of protein intake throughout the day, nor a moderate but sufficient daily protein intake significantly affects muscle gains.

title: Did it rain or snow on ancient Mars? New study suggests it did
snippets: Geologists weigh in on a long-running debate about Mars: Billions of years ago, was the Red Planet warm and wet or cold and dry?
titles: Did it rain or snow on ancient Mars? New study suggests it did
summary: Geologists have engaged in a detailed analysis to address a longstanding debate regarding Mars' ancient climate conditions. They are examining whether, billions of years ago, Mars was characterized by a warm and wet environment or was predominantly cold and dry. This research aims to provide clarity on the Red Planet's historical climate, contributing to our understanding of its potential to have supported life.

title: Building 'cellular bridges' for spinal cord repair after injury
snippets: Capitalizing on the flexibility of tiny cells inside the body's smallest blood vessels may be a powerful spinal cord repair strategy, new research suggests.
titles: Building 'cellular bridges' for spinal cord repair after injury
summary: New research suggests that leveraging the adaptability of microscopic cells within the body's tiniest blood vessels could offer an effective strategy for repairing spinal cord injuries. This approach focuses on the potential of these small cells to aid in the regeneration and healing of spinal cord damage.

title: Devils won't have injured defensemen Luke Hughes, Brenden Dillon for Game 2 against Hurricanes
snippets: New Jersey Devils defensemen Luke Hughes and Brenden Dillon are out with injuries for Tuesday night's Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against the Carolina Hurricanes.  Coach Sheldon Keefe ruled out both Hughes and Dillon after neither participated in the morning skate.  Keefe didn't specify the nature of those injuries, which are another hit for a squad that was already down prominent pieces before the Stanley Cup Playoffs.
titles: Devils won't have injured defensemen Luke Hughes, Brenden Dillon for Game 2 against Hurricanes
summary: New Jersey Devils defensemen Luke Hughes and Brenden Dillon will miss Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against the Carolina Hurricanes due to injuries. Coach Sheldon Keefe confirmed their absence after both players did not participate in the morning skate. The specific nature of their injuries was not disclosed. This development adds to the challenges for the Devils, who were already facing the loss of key players heading into the Stanley Cup Playoffs.

title: Wisconsin relies on new QB and coordinator to boost an offense that has struggled under Luke Fickell
snippets: The team is coming off its first losing season in more than two decades. If the Badgers don’t bounce back, plenty of people could be on thin ice.
titles: Wisconsin relies on new QB and coordinator to boost an offense that has struggled under Luke Fickell
summary: The Badgers, having experienced their first losing season in over 20 years, face pressure to improve their performance. If they fail to bounce back, it could jeopardize the positions of numerous individuals involved with the team.

title: New York Giants' Tyler Nubin explains switch to jersey No. 27
snippets: New York Giants safety Tyler Nubin is changing his number from 31 to 27, the same number he wore as a Minnesota Golden Gopher.
titles: New York Giants' Tyler Nubin explains switch to jersey No. 27
summary: Tyler Nubin, a safety for the New York Giants, has decided to change his jersey number from 31 to 27, reverting to the same number he wore during his college football career with the Minnesota Golden Gophers.
